item.title: George Osbourne Warns of Brexit Risks and Cuts Growth Forecasts
item.description: The British treasury chief also unveiled tax cuts and more resources for education, as well as a tax on sugary drinks, in his annual budget presentation.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, center, visited a construction site for a rail line in central London on Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Honduras: Activist’s Colleague Is Killed
item.description: Gunmen killed Nelson García, a colleague of the environmentalist leader Berta Cáceres, who was slain almost two weeks ago under similar circumstances.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea’s History of Seizing Americans
item.description: Roughly a dozen Americans have been held for varying lengths of time by North Korea in the past several years. Most were eventually released.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Otto F. Warmbier, an American college student, was escorted at North Korea’s Supreme Court in Pyongyang on Wednesday. He was sentenced to 15 years of hard labor.

item.title: World Briefing: Morocco: U.N. Chief Angers Officials
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon recently described Morocco’s hold on the Western Sahara territory as an occupation.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Qatar: Jailed Poet Is Freed, U.N. Says
item.description: The poet, Muhammad ibn al-Dheeb al-Ajami, was pardoned after serving part of a 15-year sentence over verses he wrote that apparently offended the government of the nation’s former ruler.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Poland’s Tatars Feel Uncertain as Anti-Muslim Sentiment Grows
item.description: Lipka Tatars, despite 600-year-old roots in Poland, increasingly find themselves navigating between religion and nationality as the country argues over accepting migrants.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: RYAN SCHUESSLER
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dzenneta and Tamara Bogdanowicz, Polish Muslims, visited the grave of Tamara’s husband in Kruszyniany, Poland, last week. He died in October after 58 years of marriage.

item.title: E.U. Aims to Revise Proposed Migrants Deal With Turkey
item.description: The plan, brokered by Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, would include accelerated prospects for Turkey to join the European Union.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein Leader, Skips White House Visit Over Security
item.description: The Irish politician was stopped at the gates for a lengthy security check when he arrived to attend a St. Patrick’s Day celebration.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: As France Razes Calais Camp, Some Ask Where Migrants Will Go
item.description: Workers finished dismantling part of the so-called Jungle camp, but many migrants have resisted relocation to state-sanctioned centers.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: French riot police kept watch Wednesday as part of the migrant camp in Calais was dismantled.

item.title: Ex-President ‘Lula’ Joins Brazil’s Cabinet, Gaining Legal Shield
item.description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, facing multiple corruption investigations, will become President Dilma Rousseff’s chief of staff, a position that offers him increased protection.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, a former president of Brazil, in front of his home in São Bernardo do Campo on Sunday.

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: A Rich Family’s Clout
item.description: A senior government official said that a wealthy family close to President Jacob Zuma had offered him a cabinet position, a revelation that added to corruption allegations against the president.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea Sentences Otto Warmbier, U.S. Student, to 15 Years’ Labor
item.description: Mr. Warmbier, an undergraduate at the University of Virginia who tried to steal a propaganda poster, was convicted of subversion.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Sisterhood of the Easter Rising
item.description: A century after its symbolic foundation, the Irish republic should repay its debt to women.
item.dc:creator: SADHBH WALSHE
item.media:description: Constance Markievicz was second in command at the rebels’ St. Stephen’s Green outpost in Dublin.

item.title: Syrian Kurds Hope to Establish a Federal Region in Country’s North
item.description: Such a move would fall well short of declaring independence but would most likely rile both the government and the main Arab-led opposition group.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A member of a Kurdish militia on the eastern side of the Euphrates River in Sarrin, Syria, in October.

item.title: Putin Warns Against Politicizing Doping Scandal
item.description: Russia’s president also criticized his nation’s sports officials for their handling of a scandal that has touched a number of the country’s athletes.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Readers Speak Out: Living in a Germany Reshaped by Migration
item.description: The Times asked longtime residents and recent arrivals in the country to share their experiences.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times

item.title: Denmark Ranks as Happiest Country; Burundi, Not So Much
item.description: At the bottom of the World Happiness Report, a list of more than 150 countries, was Burundi, where a violent political crisis broke out last year.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Denmark has topped the World Happiness Report every year but one since 2012.

item.title: Germany Bans Neo-Nazi Group as Far-Right Gains From Migration Crisis
item.description: The move against White Wolves Terrorcrew is intended to demonstrate that the authorities will not tolerate agitation against foreigners and migrants.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: French Student Who ‘Took Some Breaks’ Earns Doctorate at 90
item.description: Colette Bourlier became one of the oldest people in France to be awarded the degree, 30 years after she first began researching immigrant workers.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Colette Bourlier defended her thesis at the Université de Franche-Comté in Besançon, France, on Tuesday.

item.title: Belgium Says Algerian Killed in Raid May Have Had Links to Radical Islam
item.description: Mohamed Belkaid, a 35-year-old who was in Belgium illegally, tried to open fire on officers and was shot and killed by a special forces sniper.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: The building in Brussels where a man was killed during a counterterrorism raid on Tuesday. Police officers found a flag of the Islamic State, a book on the Salafist school of Islam and a Kalashnikov rifle during the operation.
